4. The brutalization effect is a theory that the death penalty may actually increase homicides by desensitizing people to killing and sending the message that violence is an acceptable solution. Some research supports this, but it remains controversial.

5. International comparisons show that the U.S., which uses the death penalty more than almost any other developed country, has much higher homicide rates than countries that have abolished it. However, many confounding factors make it difficult to draw firm conclusions from this.

In summary, while a few studies claim to show a deterrent effect, the bulk of the research and expert opinion suggests the death penalty does not deter crime more than life imprisonment.
